key_points: Colin Powell, the first Black US secretary of state, has died from complications from Covid-19 at the age of 84.
Powell was fully vaccinated against Covid-19 but was at greater risk due to multiple myeloma and Parkinson's disease.
His career included roles such as Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and national security adviser.
Powell's reputation was marred by his involvement in pushing faulty intelligence before the UN to advocate for the Iraq War.
He became disillusioned with the Republican Party's direction and endorsed Barack Obama in 2008.
Powell is survived by his wife, Alma Vivian Powell, and their three children. Alma Powell also tested positive for Covid-19 but exhibited mild symptoms.
Over 7,000 breakthrough Covid-19 cases resulting in death have been reported among the fully vaccinated in the US, with the majority being among those aged 65 and older.
Leaders including President Joe Biden, former VP Dick Cheney, and former Secretary of State Madeleine Albright have expressed their condolences and highlighted Powell's legacy.
Powell was remembered as a trailblazer, role model, and a person of high integrity and principles by those who knew him.
Born to Jamaican immigrants in Harlem, Powell's military career began after graduating from the City College of New York and included two tours in South Vietnam.
spokespersons: Peggy Cifrino (Colin Powell's longtime chief of staff)
